title: Java Encapsulation and Getters and Setters

content.text: The meaning of Encapsulation , is to make sure that "sensitive" data is hidden from users. To achieve this, you must:
content.html: The meaning of Encapsulation, is to make sure that "sensitive" data is hidden from users. To achieve this, you must:

content.text: You learned from the previous chapter that private variables can only be accessed within the same class (an outside class has no access to it). However, it is possible to access them if we provide public get and set methods.
content.html: You learned from the previous chapter that private variables can only be accessed within the same class (an outside class has no access to it). However, it is possible to access them if we provide public get and set methods.

content.text: The get method returns the variable value, and the set method sets the value.
content.html: The get method returns the variable value, and the set method sets the value.

content.text: Syntax for both is that they start with either get or set , followed by the name of the variable, with the first letter in upper case:
content.html: Syntax for both is that they start with either get or set, followed by the name of the variable, with the first letter in upper case:

content.code_html:
public class Person {
  private String name; // private = restricted access

  // Getter
  public String getName() {
    return name;
  }

  // Setter
  public void setName(String newName) {
    this.name = newName;
  }
}

content.text: The get method returns the value of the variable name .
content.html: The get method returns the value of the variable name.

content.text: The set method takes a parameter ( newName ) and assigns it to the name variable. The this keyword is used to refer to the current object.
content.html: The set method takes a parameter (newName) and assigns it to the name variable. The this keyword is used to refer to the current object.

content.text: However, as the name variable is declared as private , we cannot access it from outside this class:
content.html: However, as the name variable is declared as private, we cannot access it from outside this class:

content.code_html:
public class Main {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Person myObj = new Person();
    myObj.name = "John";  // error
    System.out.println(myObj.name); // error 
  }
}

content.text: If the variable was declared as public , we would expect the following output:
content.html: If the variable was declared as public, we would expect the following output:

content.code_html: John

content.text: However, as we try to access a private variable, we get an error:
content.html: However, as we try to access a private variable, we get an error:

content.code_html:
MyClass.java:4: error: name has private access in Person
    myObj.name = "John";
         ^
MyClass.java:5: error: name has private access in Person
    System.out.println(myObj.name);
                  ^
2 errors

content.text: Instead, we use the getName() and setName() methods to access and update the variable:
content.html: Instead, we use the getName() and setName() methods to access and update the variable:

content.code_html:
public class Main {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Person myObj = new Person();
    myObj.setName("John"); // Set the value of the name variable to "John"
    System.out.println(myObj.getName());
  }
}

// Outputs "John"

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is the meaning of Encapsulation in Java?
content.html: What is the meaning of Encapsulation in Java?

metadata.question: What is the meaning of Encapsulation in Java?

options.text: To create special classes that represents a group of constants
Used to set initial values for object attributes
Make sure that sensitive data is hidden from users
To inherit attributes and methods from one class to another

content.question: What is the meaning of Encapsulation in Java?

options.text: To create special classes that represents a group of constants
Used to set initial values for object attributes
Make sure that sensitive data is hidden from users
To inherit attributes and methods from one class to another
